turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Sauer 38H.
turn.1: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.2: The Heckler & Koch P9 also utilizes a cocking/decocking lever based on the Sauer 38H.
turn.3: What kind of materials were used to make the pistol?
turn.4: The grips of the pistol were constructed of Bakelite.
turn.5: Did the pistol have any issues?
turn.6: Age often results in the cracking and crumbling of the grips on surviving examples.
turn.7: What other materials did it have?
turn.8: All original grips featured "SUS" lettering standing for "Sauer und Sohn" which could be found on the same side of the pistol as the magazine release though many reproduction grips have copied this logo.
turn.9: Were the grips easy to replace?
turn.10: It is unusual for a present-day example to have original, undamaged grips.
turn.11: What other materials did it have?
turn.12: The Sauer 38H was produced mainly for the .32 ACP cartridge, however some rare examples were also made in .380 ACP and .22 LR.
